channel.title: Home on juppytt's blog
channel.description: Recent content in Home on juppytt's blog

item.title: Black Hat USA 2024
item.description: From August 5th to 12nd 2024, I attended Black Hat USA 2024 (and Defcon 32) in Las Vegas. I presented my research on Bypassing MTE with a side-channel attack. I returned to Korea this morning (luckily, no jet lag) and am writing this post to share my experiences from Las Vegas before I forget them. Black Hat USA 2024 First Black Hat experience I’ve never been to Black Hat before, so I was very excited, especially since I was going to present for the first time in an international conference.

item.title: A review of 2023: Surprises, Triumphs, and Failures
item.description: It’s the end of 2023, and as I look back on the year, I can only say that it was a year full of research. I remember the days spent in front of the computer, reading papers, and conducting experiments. Of course, there were other events this year, including the creation of this blog (yay!). So, I decided it would be nice to write a review of 2023, to reflect on this year and to prepare for the next year.

item.title: Series: Graduate School Productivity - Introduction
item.description: Time flies in graduate school! Having spent 3.5 years as a PhD student, one thing I’ve learned is that I should be super-efficient in managing my time and energy. I’m not someone you’d label as “born productive”. I’m a typical “P”-type person according to Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI)–indicative of a spontaneous and flexible nature. As many P-type people do, I’m prone to distraction and have difficulty in sticking to routines. Daily to-do lists or planners are ways to self-torture by confining free will into a fixed schedule.

item.title: Hugging (Evil) Face: Security issues in Hugging Face
item.description: Introduction In recent years, emerging technology in Machine Learning and Large Language Model (LLM) had led to the development of ML/LLM-powered applications. One of the popular service for ML/LLM application is Hugging Face. In this post, I would like to describe the potential security risks in current Hugging Face, especially in Spaces. Hugging Face Hugging Face is a AI community that provides a lot of machine learning models, datasets, and applications.

item.title: Security-hardening ARM64 Linux kernel
item.description: Intro In the first year of my Ph.D, I ambitiously began a research on protecting the Linux kernel against data-only attacks. My research especially focused on protecting security-critical objects and pointers leveraging the ARM’s upcoming hardware security features (PAC and MTE). Building such a kernel hardening system required me to tackle several key issues: Cross-compiling the kernel (X86 -> ARM64) Cross-module kernel analysis Linux kernel instrumentation Connecting the cross-module analysis with kernel build system.
